results.title: The Costume designer
results.brief_description: Explains the work of costume designers in the production of a feature motion picture. The costume designer must create - whether for one star or a mob scene - costumes that are appropriate - historically, geographically and, most important, dramatically. The designer must have each design, plus the cost breakdown, approved by the director, producer, and art director. To make any improvements needed, the costume designer stays on the set until production ends.

results.title: Cosmic rays
results.creator_credit: Hugh Odishaw, Stanley Ruttenberg, Lothar Wolff and National Academy of Sciences (U.S.)
results.brief_description: Deals with the radiations observed on earth and first identified early in this century as a phenomenon originating in outer space. Current concepts of their origin are presented and their study related to other fields of scientific research, such as atomic and nuclear physics.

results.title: 'Cos it's naughty (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Edward Goldwyn and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Children Thinking”.
Interaction between parent and child in the child’s growing understanding of right and wrong. How does the child know what a lie is? How can the child begin understanding the framework of good and naughty imposed on them by adults?

results.title: The Australian ballet - Corroboree
results.brief_description: ‘Corroboree’ is both a record of the world premiere of the famous ballet created in Australia, and a behind-the-scenes glimpse of the rehearsal, design and preparation that went into the production. Inspired by composer John Antill’s best known work, the ballet was sponsored by the Arts Council of Australia and choreographed by Rex Reid. Performed by the National Theatre Ballet Company and the Sydney Symphony Orchestra, ‘Corroboree’ is a striking illustration of some of the ways in which white Australia has imagined and expropriated Australian First Nations cultures.

results.title: Correlieu (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Jean Palardy, Louis Portugais and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: The life and philosophy of the Quebec painter, Ozias Leduc, traced through his own paintings and scenes of his home, “Correlieu”, and the surrounding countryside. His technique and its influence on other painters is demonstrated, and his consciousness of the turbulent modern schools that came and went during his long lifetime is revealed. Included are some of the large paintings he did for cathedrals and churches. Narrated by George Whalley.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jean Palardy, Louis Portugais and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Corral
results.creator_credit: Colin Low, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: The roping and riding of a high-spirited half-broken horse is the subject of a film which makes visual poetry of this theme. Movement and music combine to tel a story without words, set in the foothills of Alberta, as we watch a cowboy perform a task which is part of a centuries-old tradition of the West. The music, played on guitar, is an original score containing variations on Western Ballad. (Five awards, including Venice; Edinburgh)

results.title: Corot 1796-1875
results.brief_description: A survey of the works of Corot, a painter of joy and happiness who opened the door for the Impressionists by mingling the dream-life of Romanticism with the clean cool lines of the classical tradition.
results.description: A survey of the works of Corot, a painter of joy and happiness who opened the door for the Impressionists by mingling the dream-life of Romanticism with the clean cool lines of the classical tradition.

results.title: A Coronation in the Himalayas
results.creator_credit: N.S. Thapa, M. Bhavnani and Documentary Films of India
results.brief_description: The coronation of the Maharaja of Bhutan in October 1952. The camerman trekked eight days by mule to the remote city of Paro to film the occasion. Bhutanese troops, some in modern uniform and others in ancient Mongolian-style battle dress with shields and helmets, turn out to welcome the party. Processions of Indian troops, Bhutanese troops and lamas on the Coronation Day; the Coronation ceremony performed by Lamas and marked by the presentation of ceremonial scarves to the royal couple; the traditional dancing after the ceremony.
results.creator_credit_for_label: N.S. Thapa, M. Bhavnani and Documentary Films of India

results.title: Coronation day
results.creator_credit: Thorold Dickinson, United Nations Films and United Nations. Office of Public Information
results.brief_description: Captures the coronation day of Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth II on the 2nd June, 1953. Shows the procession from Buckingham Palace to Westminster Abbey, the coronation service, the procession back to the Palace and Her Majesty’s appearance on the balcony to watch the R.A.F. fly-past. Includes a glimpse of Sir Robert Menzies at the ceremony. Commentary by James McKechnie, script by Gerald Sanger.
